Archives at risk in 2023: Ukraine's archives

As of April 2023, three national and state libraries and 25 university libraries in Ukraine have been severely damaged or destroyed by oncoming Russian troops. This included the Karazin University library, which held rare books, early manuscripts and important Ukrainian archival collections.
dialogs.answer: 'The destruction of knowledge and erasure of memory has always been a war aim for those who seek to impose their own version of history on the next generation' writes Richard Ovenden, librarian at Oxford's Bodley library, in The Altantic (Ovenden, 2023). Apart from the destruction of Ukrainian libraries and archives due to military attacks, there are reports of troops dumping books in brine, destroying Ukrainian historical literature, and seizing archival documents containing accounts of abuse of Ukrainians during the Soviet period. What can be done for archives at risk of destruction?

The spate of looting, according to Sudanese writer Reem Abbas as quoted in The New Arab, is “an attempt to cripple the country’s economy and destroy what is left of the infrastructure we have in Sudan”
(Cooper, 2023, para. 16).
dialogs.text: The archives of Omdurman Ahlia University containing thousands of documents, historical works, primary sources and PhD theses were set ablaze by looters during the 2023 armed conflict in Sudan.
